items.title: Meta CTO says staff should quit if they don’t like Meta’s new policies
items.summary:
- Meta CTO Andrew Bosworth stated employees unhappy with new policies are welcome to quit.
- His remarks followed complaints about layoffs and cuts to DEI programs from employees.
- Bosworth emphasized that leaking internal disagreements should lead to considering alternate employment.
- The firm has started layoffs that have been criticized as unfair by staff, who feel demoralized and disrespected.
- Internal discussions reflect significant turmoil as Meta adjusts major policies, including relaxing content moderation standards.

items.title: Google Gemini now brings receipts to your AI chats
items.author: Maxwell Zeff
items.summary:
- Google’s Gemini AI can now tailor responses based on past conversations.
- Launching the recall feature for English-speaking subscribers of Google One AI Premium at $20/month.
- Users can manage their chat history, including deletion and recall capabilities, addressing privacy concerns.

items.title: Arm is launching its own chip this year with Meta as a customer
items.summary:
- Arm is starting its own chip production in 2025 with Meta as a customer.
- The chips will primarily be CPUs for large data center servers and customizable for various clients.
- The first in-house Arm chip is expected to be unveiled by summer 2025.
- This marks a strategic shift for Arm, which typically licenses its chip designs to other companies like Apple and Nvidia.

items.title: OpenAI removes certain content warnings from ChatGPT
items.author: Kyle Wiggers
items.summary:
- OpenAI has removed warning messages in ChatGPT indicating potential violations of terms of service.
- The change aims to reduce unnecessary denials and enhance user experience, without allowing harmful or false content.
- Users can now engage in broader discussions, including topics previously flagged, such as mental health and erotica.
- This move follows updates to OpenAI's Model Spec, which emphasizes openness on sensitive topics.
- The decision may be influenced by political pressure and claims of censorship against conservative viewpoints.

items.title: Eon Musk’s full offer letter to buy OpenAI reveals five key details
items.author: Charles Rollet
items.summary:
- A consortium led by Elon Musk’s x.AI offered $97.4 billion to buy OpenAI, dismissed by CEO Sam Altman.
- The offer has a deadline of May 10, 2025, but OpenAI's board has not formally rejected it yet.
- The transaction will be all-cash, with 100% of the purchase price paid in cash, unlike Musk’s previous debt-financed deals.
- Musk's team wants access to OpenAI’s financial records and personnel prior to the purchase.
- Musk may withdraw his bid if OpenAI maintains its non-profit status, which contradicts his ongoing lawsuit claims.

items.title: Tim Cook teases Apple product news for February 19 — likely the iPhone SE
items.summary:
- Apple CEO Tim Cook announced a new product arrival on February 19, likely a fourth-generation iPhone SE.
- The previous iPhone SE was released three years ago at a price of $429, and Apple aims to replace the Touch ID with Face ID.
- The new iPhone SE is expected to use the same chip as the iPhone 16, enabling generative AI capabilities through Apple's intelligence.

items.title: Anthropic’s next major AI model could arrive within weeks
items.author: Not given
items.summary:
- AI startup Anthropic is set to release its next major AI model, described as a ‘hybrid’ capable of deep reasoning and fast responses.
- The model will include a ‘sliding scale’ feature for developers to manage costs associated with deeper reasoning tasks.
- Anthropic’s upcoming model is anticipated to outperform OpenAI’s o3-mini-high reasoning model in programming tasks and is effective at analyzing large codebases.
- CEO Dario Amodei expressed a focus on differentiating reasoning models in a recent interview.

items.title: Phase raises $13M to speed up the UX design process with its no-code platform
items.author: Kate Park
items.summary:
- Phase, founded by Nick Budden, has raised $13 million to enhance the no-code design workflow for UI/UX designers.
- The startup's platform allows designers to create interactive prototypes without coding, aiming to replace tools like Figma and Adobe After Effects.
- Phase successfully launched its platform in South Korea, achieving over 10,000 testers shortly after launch, with plans to expand into U.S. and European markets.

items.title: Another robotaxi operation heads to Texas and Archer scores $300M for its defense mission
items.author: Kirsten Korosec, Sean O’Kane, Rebecca Bellan
items.summary:
- Archer Aviation raised $300 million from investors to enhance its hybrid vertical take-off and landing aircraft program in collaboration with Anduril.
- This funding brings 
Archer's total raised to approximately $3.36 billion.
- The article discusses the increasing robotaxi operations in Texas, with companies like Lyft, Waymo, and Tesla planning to launch services in the state in 2025.

items.title: Tofu is building an omni-channel marketing platform for enterprises
items.author: EJ Cho
items.summary:
- Tofu, founded by EJ Cho, is an AI-driven B2B marketing platform designed for enterprises.
- The platform aims to unify various marketing campaigns and integrates with tools like HubSpot and Salesforce.
- Launched in late 2023, Tofu has achieved 12x revenue growth and raised $12 million in Series A funding, attracting customers like DeepScribe and Check Point.
- Tofu's approach focuses on personalization and repurposing content across different channels based on insights gathered from CMOs.
- The company aims to provide a comprehensive solution rather than being a single-use tool, positioning itself effectively in a crowded market.

items.title: OpenAI scrubs diversity commitment web page from its site
items.author: Dominic-Madori Davis
items.summary:
- OpenAI removed its diversity, equity, and inclusion commitment page, redirecting it to a new page emphasizing people with different backgrounds.
- The previous commitment stated a serious and ongoing investment in DEI, captured by [Internet Archive](https://web.archive.org/) and cited by [CNN](https://www.cnn.com/2023/12/15/tech/openai-board-diversity/index.html).
- The change likely took place between January 22 and January 27, 2025, coinciding with a trend among tech companies distancing from DEI language due to political backlash.
- OpenAI has not commented on whether internal processes have changed following this removal, while still maintaining a page on [fairness](https://openai.com/index/evaluating-fairness-in-chatgpt/) in its model training.

items.title: Seagate acquires Intevac, which makes equipment for hard disk drives, for $119M
items.author: Kyle Wiggers
items.summary:
- Seagate announced its intent to acquire Intevac for $119 million in an all-cash deal.
- The agreement includes a tender offer of $4 per share for at least 50% of Intevac’s shares, followed by a merger for the remaining shares.
- The acquisition is expected to close in late March or early April 2025, pending customary conditions.
- Intevac, founded in 1991, specializes in thin film deposition systems and has a market cap of around $91.17 million.
- The move aligns with Seagate's strategy in the storage market, particularly with HAMR technology for hard drives.
- This is Seagate's first major acquisition since 2017, bringing its total to 11 acquisitions.

items.title: A comprehensive list of 2024 and 2025 tech layoffs
items.summary:
- In 2024, over 150,000 job cuts across 542 tech companies occurred.
- Companies like [Tesla](https://techcrunch.com/2024/04/15/tesla-layoffs-workers-sales-cybertruck-cuts/), [Amazon](https://techcrunch.com/2024/01/10/amazon-prime-video-and-mgm-studios-laid-off-hundreds-of-employees/), [Google](https://techcrunch.com/2024/01/10/google-cuts-hundreds-of-jobs-in-its-voice-assistance-hardware-teams-as-fitbit-founders-leave/), and [Microsoft](https://techcrunch.com/2024/01/25/microsoft-lays-off-1900-employees-in-activision-blizzard-and-xbox-divisions/) were among those making sizable layoffs.
- A comprehensive layoff tracking for 2024 and 2025 will be updated regularly, with the first significant cuts reported in January 2025.

items.title: Valve removes Steam game that contained malware
items.author: Lorenzo Franceschi-Bicchierai
items.summary:
- Valve removed the game *PirateFi* from Steam due to malware presence.
- Users are advised to fully reformat their operating systems.
- The game had a 9/10 rating from 51 reviews before removal.
- Valve urges users to run a full-system scan and check for unexpected software.
- The type of malware has not been specified by Valve.

items.title: Alibaba confirms Apple deal bringing AI features to iPhones in China
items.author: Brian Heater
items.summary:
- Alibaba has confirmed a partnership with Apple to implement AI features in iPhones sold in China.
- The partnership arises as Apple faces declining iPhone sales in the Chinese market, with an 11% year-over-year drop.
- Alibaba's chairman Joseph Tsai noted the collaboration during the World Government Summit in Dubai, emphasizing the honor of partnering with Apple.
- Previous partnerships with Baidu and others faced issues, making this alliance crucial for Apple's strategy in China.
- Apple aims to leverage AI to improve sales and compete against local rivals like Vivo and Huawei, which have gained market share.

items.title: Startup Battlefield 200: The competition starts on the waitlist
items.summary:
- TechCrunch’s Startup Battlefield 200 is a pitch competition for innovative early-stage startups, taking place from October 27-29, 2025, at Disrupt 2025 in San Francisco.
- Startups can join a waitlist to gain priority access for applications, showcasing their ideas to renowned VCs.
- Benefits include global exposure, feedback from top investors, potential to win $100,000 in equity-free funding, and various networking opportunities.

items.title: EU’s Disinformation Code moves closer to becoming DSA benchmark
items.summary:
- The European Union's Code of Practice on Disinformation is set to be integrated into the Digital Services Act (DSA) framework by July 1, 2025.
- The DSA requires platforms to manage systemic risks related to disinformation, and the Code offers guidelines for compliance.
- Signatories must take actions like removing financial incentives for disinformation and focusing on service integrity, such as eliminating bots and fake accounts.
- Controversy arises as platforms like Meta have weakened their commitment to fact-checking while remaining signatories of the Code.
- The Commission has endorsed this integration, which will lead to auditable commitments by the stated date.

items.title: Honda’s $60B merger with Nissan falls apart
items.summary:
- The $60 billion merger between Honda and Nissan has been canceled due to Nissan's pride and concerns about its situation.
- Honda revised merger terms, suggesting Nissan become a subsidiary.
- Foxconn is now considering buying a stake in Nissan since the merger is off.
- The merger talks were formally announced in December 2024, aimed at surviving changes in the automotive industry.
- If completed, the merger would have formed the world's third-largest automaker, potentially involving Mitsubishi as well.

items.title: Publishers sue AI startup Cohere over alleged copyright infringement
items.summary:
- A consortium of fourteen publishers including Condé Nast, The Atlantic, and Forbes has filed a lawsuit against Cohere for alleged copyright infringement.
- The lawsuit claims Cohere used at least 4,000 copyrighted works to train its AI models and displayed large portions or entire articles, negatively affecting publishers’ referral traffic.
- Cohere's head of communications, Josh Gartner, stated that the company stands by its practices, considers the lawsuit misguided, and expects a favorable resolution.
- This lawsuit is part of a broader trend of legal challenges against AI companies over intellectual property rights.

items.title: Germany’s Helsing doubles down on drones for Ukraine, scales up manufacturing
items.author: Anna Heim
items.summary:
- Helsing, backed by Daniel Ek, is producing 6,000 HX-2 strike drones in addition to 4,000 HF-1 drones for Ukraine.
- Production is scaled up due to additional orders from Ukraine following talks between U.S. and Russian leaders.
- The HX-2 drone integrates AI and can be manufactured at scale, supporting lower costs and swarming capabilities.
- Helsing's first 'Resilience Factory' in Southern Germany is operational with a capacity of over 1,000 HX-2 units monthly.
- The startup raised $487 million in a Series C funding round, contributing to Europe's defense funding leadership in 2024.
- The Munich Security Conference and strategic partnership with Mistral highlight Europe's focus on geopolitical and AI initiatives.

items.title: Blue Origin cuts 10% of staff one month after first successful New Glenn launch
items.author: Not given
items.summary:
- Blue Origin is laying off 10% of its workforce, approximately 1,000 employees out of over 10,000, following the first successful launch of its New Glenn mega-rocket.
- CEO Dave Limp announced the layoffs during an all-hands meeting, citing that the company was not prepared for the success it aimed for.
- Limp became CEO in 2023 and acknowledged that the company and the New Glenn program faced delays while competitors like SpaceX thrived.

items.title: Spyware maker caught distributing malicious Android apps for years
items.summary:
- Italian spyware maker SIO is accused of distributing malicious Android apps that disguise themselves as popular applications like WhatsApp.
- Security researchers found these apps to be spyware confirmed by Lookout and Google.
- The spyware, named Spyrtacus, can steal texts, monitor calls, and access photos, implicating government use in Italy for surveillance purposes.
- SIO has previously supplied spyware to the Italian government and the malicious apps were developed to be user-friendly and deceptive.
- The campaign raises concerns about government surveillance and the methods used to target individuals through malware.

items.title: YouTube Shorts adds Veo 2 so creators can make gen AI videos
items.author: Amanda Silberling
items.summary:
- YouTube Shorts integrates with Google DeepMind's video model, Veo 2, enabling creators to generate AI video clips.
- Veo 2 offers advancements over the Dream Screen feature, allowing for the generation of standalone video clips with specified styles and effects.
- Videos made with AI will be watermarked using DeepMind's SynthID, and labeled to indicate they are AI-generated as the feature rolls out on February 15, 2024 for creators in select countries.

items.title: EnCharge raises $100M+ to accelerate AI using analog chips
items.author: Naveen Verma
items.summary:
- EnCharge AI, a semiconductor startup, has secured over $100 million in a Series B round led by Tiger Global.
- The funding will support the development of analog memory chips intended for AI applications across various devices.
- EnCharge claims its chips use 20 times less energy than competing products and aims to bring these to market later this year.
- The U.S. government is focusing on boosting domestic chip production, positioning EnCharge as a potential key player in this strategy.
- Other investors in the round include Maverick Silicon, Capital TEN, and Samsung Ventures among others.
- The company collaborates with TSMC for the manufacturing of its chips, which are designed for efficient AI processing at the edge.

items.title: Data center tweaks could unlock 76 GW of new power capacity in the U.S.
items.author: Tim De Chant
items.summary:
- The U.S. may unlock 76 GW of new power capacity by slightly reducing data center power consumption for a few hours annually.
- By limiting usage to 90% of maximum draw, data centers can contribute significantly to managing peak electricity demand.
- Flexible power use strategies, such as shifting tasks to off-peak hours or using alternative power sources like batteries, can enhance demand response capabilities.

items.title: CyberArk snaps up Zilla Security for up to $175M
items.author: Paul Sawers
items.summary:
- CyberArk has acquired Zilla Security for up to $175 million, consisting of $165 million in cash and $10 million in earn-outs.
- The deal aims to enhance CyberArk's offerings with Zilla's purpose-built cloud IGA capabilities.
- Zilla, founded in 2019, adds AI-driven features and automation, appealing to CyberArk’s modernization efforts.

items.title: Avride launches sidewalk delivery bots on Uber Eats in Jersey City
items.author: Rebecca Bellan
items.summary:
- Uber Eats launches autonomous sidewalk delivery bots by Avride in Jersey City.
- The launch is part of Uber's expanding relationship with Avride, which includes partnerships in 11 cities targeting delivery services.
- Customers can choose between traditional couriers and Avride robots for their deliveries.
- Bots can operate in snow and moderate precipitation, traveling up to 5 mph with a range of 31 miles on a single charge.
- Deliveries cover one square mile in downtown Jersey City, with plans for future expansion.
- Customers receive notifications when their bot arrives and can unlock it through the Uber Eats app to retrieve their orders.
- CEO Dara Khosrowshahi noted that the autonomous vehicle industry represents a trillion-dollar opportunity in the U.S.

items.title: Sophos lays off 6% of workforce following Secureworks acquisition
items.author: Sara Eberle
items.summary:
- Sophos, a U.K. cybersecurity firm, is laying off 6% of its workforce after acquiring Secureworks for $859 million.
- The layoffs were reported less than two weeks post-acquisition and affect roughly 6% of the combined companies.
- The reduction is due to positions no longer needed after Secureworks’ delisting and streamlining of roles post-acquisition.
- In 2023, Sophos previously laid off 10% of its workforce to maintain growth and profitability.

items.title: Apple’s app tracking privacy framework could fall foul of German antitrust rules
items.author: Natasha Lomas
items.summary:
- Germany's antitrust watchdog, Bundeskartellamt (FCO), is investigating Apple's app privacy framework since 2022.
- FCO suspects Apple may not treat third-party app developers equally, potentially amounting to self-preferencing.
- New regulations under the Digital Markets Act prohibit self-preferencing by big tech on iOS and core platform services like the App Store.
- The investigation focuses on Apple's App Tracking Transparency framework, which treats third-party tracking permissions differently than its own.
- Concerns were raised about unequal treatment in consent dialogues and the strict application of tracking definitions against third-party apps.
- Apple is given the opportunity to respond to the FCO's findings prior to any formal advocacy or acting on it.

items.title: Apptronik, which makes humanoid robots, raises $350M as category heats up
items.author: Brian Heater
items.summary:
- Apptronik announced a $350 million Series A funding round, co-led by B Capital and Capital Factory, with participation from Google.
- CEO Jeff Cardenas emphasized the focus on demonstrating useful work with early adopters in 2025 and scaling in 2026.
- The Austin-based startup aims to expand its workforce by 50% over the next year and is currently working on pilot programs with companies like Mercedes.

items.title: Mercedes-AMG Petronas F1 team steers toward nature-based carbon credits
items.author: Tim De Chant
items.summary:
- Formula 1 aims to achieve net-zero carbon emissions by 2030, despite cars contributing less than 1% of a team's carbon footprint.
- Mercedes-AMG Petronas is purchasing 5,500 metric tons of carbon credits from Chestnut Carbon to offset emissions, expected to be delivered from 2027 to 2030.
- The carbon credits account for about 10% of the team's emissions in 2023, with a goal to reduce emissions by 75% by 2030 and reach net-zero by 2040.

items.title: Telegram releases improved sticker search and video consumption features
items.author: Ivan Mehta
items.summary:
- Telegram has released updates that enhance sticker search and video consumption features.
- The improved AI-powered sticker search allows for queries across millions of stickers, increasing from a previous limit of 40,000 stickers.
- Users can now share video links with exact timestamps and choose video cover images like thumbnails.
- New features also allow users to save their video progress and resume watching later.

items.title: Barcelona-based spyware startup Variston reportedly shuts down
items.author: Not given
items.summary:
- Variston, a Barcelona-based spyware vendor, is reportedly being liquidated as per a legal notice published on February 10, 2025.
- The liquidation follows reports that the company was in the process of shutting down after losing several employees last year.
- Variston was founded in 2018 by Ralf Wegener and Ramanan Jayaraman and had operated in secrecy until a Google report highlighted its existence in 2022, which may have contributed to its decline.

items.title: Docker’s new CEO is former Oracle Cloud exec Don Johnson
items.author: Paul Sawers
items.summary:
- Don Johnson, former Oracle Cloud Infrastructure executive, becomes Docker's new CEO starting Wednesday.
- Scott Johnston, the incumbent CEO, left the company immediately.
- Johnson previously worked at AWS and was pivotal in Oracle's transition to cloud services.
- Docker aims to expand its focus on developer tooling and cloud-based services under Johnson’s leadership.
- The company is looking to tackle challenges faced by developers, especially with the convergence of AI and cloud technologies.

items.title: China’s Salt Typhoon hackers continue to breach telecom firms despite US sanctions
items.author: Carly Page
items.summary:
- Security researchers report that Salt Typhoon, a hacking group linked to the Chinese government, continues to breach telecom firms despite US sanctions.
- Recorded Future observed the group compromising five telecom providers from December 2024 to January 2025.
- Previous breaches included major US companies like AT&T and Verizon, targeting communications of senior officials.
- Recent victims include a US affiliate of a UK telecom provider and companies in Italy, South Africa, and Thailand.
- Salt Typhoon exploited vulnerabilities in Cisco devices, aiming to compromise over 1,000 globally.
- The US government has sanctioned firms associated with the group but anticipates continued attacks on telecoms.

items.title: Elon Musk will withdraw bid for OpenAI’s nonprofit if its board agrees to terms
items.author: Kyle Wiggers
items.summary:
- Elon Musk will withdraw his $97.4 billion bid for OpenAI’s nonprofit if the board agrees to halt its conversion to a for-profit corporation.
- Musk's filing to the U.S. District Court emphasizes that the offer is serious and insists on preserving the charity’s mission.
- OpenAI’s board quickly rejected Musk's bid as it does not value the nonprofit and asserts that it is not for sale.
- Musk has previously sued OpenAI, claiming anticompetitive behavior and fraud.

items.title: Coinbase eyes re-entry to India
items.author: Manish Singh
items.summary:
- Coinbase is planning to re-enter the Indian market after ceasing operations over a year ago.
- The company is engaging with the Financial Intelligence Unit (FIU) for necessary approvals to operate in India.
- Previous launch in 2022 was halted due to lack of recognition from India's National Payments Corporation.
- Coinbase aims to comply with regulatory requirements while exploring global expansion.
- The crypto market in India is small, impacted by tax regulations introduced in 2022.
- A potential re-entry could help fill the gap left by the collapse of the Indian exchange WazirX.

items.title: Getaround abruptly shuts down US car-sharing operations
items.author: Kirsten Korosec
items.summary:
- Getaround is ceasing U.S. operations after previously cutting 30% of its North American workforce.
- The company is shifting focus to its European business where it operates in six countries.
- Customers were urged to return rentals to avoid liability issues, with coverage ending if vehicles are not returned.
- Getaround will incur charges of $1.5 million to $2 million due to the layoffs, with most U.S. employees ending their employment by February 14, 2025.

items.title: US pharma giant Merck backs healthcare marketplace HD in Southeast Asia
items.summary:
- Merck Sharp & Dohme (MSD) invests $7.8 million in Thai healthcare startup HD, marking its first healthtech investment in Asia Pacific.
- HD's marketplace, HDmall, offers services from over 2,500 healthcare providers, including hospitals and clinics, to digitize the medical industry in Southeast Asia.
- The platform aims to reach 5,000 providers and 600,000 patients by 2025, with $100 million in annual gross transaction volume and 400,000 paying customers in Thailand and Indonesia.
- HD is developing an AI chatbot, Jib AI, to manage customer interactions and enhance service efficiency, aiming to integrate new AI capabilities within the next year.

items.title: Ulu Ventures sticks to its diversity strategy, raises $208M
items.author: Miriam Rivera
items.summary:
• Ulu Ventures raised $208 million for its fourth fund, remaining committed to investing in diverse founders despite others scaling back DEI programs.
• Co-founded by Miriam Rivera, the firm employs a data-driven investment strategy aimed at mitigating biases.
• The new fund is 50% larger than its previous $138 million fund raised in 2021, indicating strong support from limited partners for its diversity focus.

items.title: Elon Musk’s X will pay Trump $10M to settle lawsuit over 2021 ban
items.summary:
- Elon Musk’s X to pay Donald Trump $10 million to settle a lawsuit over his 2021 ban.
- The lawsuit arose from Twitter's decision to ban Trump after the January 6 Capitol riots.
- Trump's team considered dropping the lawsuit due to his growing relationship with Musk.
- Musk reinstated Trump's account in 2022 and invested over $250 million in Trump's 2024 campaign.
- Trump decided to proceed with the settlement despite his ties with Musk; Meta previously settled a related lawsuit for $25 million.

items.title: Latent Labs Launches with $50M to Make Biology Programmable
items.author: Simon Kohl
items.summary:
- Latent Labs, founded by former DeepMind scientist Simon Kohl, exits stealth with $50 million funding.
- The startup aims to build AI models to "make biology programmable" and collaborate with biotech companies to optimize proteins.
- Latent Labs aims to reduce reliance on wet labs for drug discovery and expedite research and development processes.

items.title: Reddit hints at expanded AI-powered search
VC industry reacts to Trump nominating a16z’s Brian Quintez for regulatory role
items.author: Dominic-Madori Davis
items.summary:
- Brian Quintenz is nominated to lead the Commodity Futures Trading Commission (CFTC) by Trump.
- He has prior experience as a commissioner at the CFTC during Trump's first administration.
- His nomination has received positive reactions from various industry leaders including Brian Armstrong of Coinbase and Bobby Franklin of the NVCA.
- The CFTC is currently facing internal controversies, including staffing issues and investigations.
- Quintenz is the latest in a series of a16z affiliates taking significant roles in the Trump administration.

items.title: OpenAI pledges that its models won’t censor viewpoints
items.summary:
- OpenAI clarifies its AI models will address sensitive topics and will not suppress any viewpoints.
- The updated Model Spec prohibits steering users towards any specific agenda, reinforcing the belief in intellectual freedom.
- This decision may be influenced by political pressures and accusations of censoring conservative viewpoints.

items.title: Elizabeth Holmes says from prison she’s ‘committed’ to ‘making healthcare solutions available to everyone’
items.author: Danielle Bacher
items.summary:
- Elizabeth Holmes gave her first interview from prison to People magazine.
- She is committed to making affordable healthcare solutions available to everyone.
- Holmes maintains she did not commit fraud despite being found guilty of four counts of fraud in 2022 and is serving an 11.25-year sentence, reduced to nine for good behavior.
- Her former partner Sunny Balwani received a 13-year sentence for 12 charges related to fraud.

items.title: Apple’s TV app, TV+ streaming service, and MLS Season Pass launches on Android
items.author: Sarah Perez
items.summary:
- Apple TV app, including Apple TV+ and MLS Season Pass, launched on Android devices.
- Supports phones, tablets, and foldables, expanding beyond the previous Google TV version.
- Users can create an Apple account directly on their device, subscription priced at $9.99/month.
- Service launches in markets where Android is prevalent, increasing user reach.
- Features popular Apple Original shows and films, and includes offline downloads and watchlists.
- MLS Season Pass available as an add-on for $12.99/month or $79/season.
- Android app optimized using Material Design; lacks in-app Store found in Apple version.
- Rollout began on February 12, 2025, coinciding with Apple TV+'s five-year mark in the streaming arena.

items.title: ChatGPT: Everything you need to know about the AI-powered chatbot
items.summary:
- ChatGPT, launched in November 2022 by OpenAI, has gained over 300 million weekly active users.
- In 2024, OpenAI partnered with Apple for generative AI offerings and released GPT-4o.
- OpenAI faces internal challenges including executive departures and lawsuits.
- In 2025, OpenAI is trying to maintain its position against competitors like DeepSeek and expand relationships with government and corporate sectors.
- New features and updates for ChatGPT include the integration of a unified model and enhanced user interaction options.

items.title: OpenAI cancels its o3 AI model in favor of a ‘unified’ next-gen release
items.author: Kyle Wiggers
items.summary:
- OpenAI cancels the o3 AI model, which was planned for early 2025 release, in favor of GPT-5, integrating existing technologies.
- CEO Sam Altman emphasized simplifying product offerings and ensuring AI is user-friendly.
- GPT-4.5, also known as Orion, is expected to launch soon as the last non-reasoning model before GPT-5.

items.title: Apple is reportedly exploring humanoid robots
items.author: Brian Heater
items.summary:
- Apple is investigating humanoid and non-humanoid robots according to analyst Ming-Chi Kuo.
- A recently published research paper explores human interactions with non-anthropomorphic robots.
- Kuo projects that mass production of robots may not occur until 2028 due to current developmental challenges.
- Apple is reportedly more focused on user perception and sensing technologies than just humanoid designs.
- The company is in the exploratory phase and could potentially integrate robots into a smart home ecosystem.
- Research published by Apple aimed to attract engineers in a competitive job market for robotics.
